## Problem
Linkup provider is returning 100% errors in all benchmark runs. From history.json:
- errors: 10, accuracy: 0.0

In searchbench/providers/linkup.py:51 the payload structure may be outdated.

Possible issues:
1. API endpoint may have changed from https://api.linkup.so/v1/search
2. outputType: sourcedAnswer may no longer be valid
3. Auth header format may have changed

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/providers/linkup.py

- Verify current Linkup API docs at https://docs.linkup.so
- Update endpoint/payload structure as needed
- Run ./scripts/searchbench debug --provider linkup --count 5

## Problem
hard.json requires specific authoritative domains that search APIs rarely surface:
- sec.gov for acquisitions
- nasa.gov for space
- rfc-editor.org for standards

This causes legitimate correct answers to fail evidence checks.

## Proposed Fix
Expand required_domains to include common authoritative sources:

Acquisitions: sec.gov, reuters.com, bloomberg.com, techcrunch.com
Space: nasa.gov, space.com, esa.int
Standards: rfc-editor.org, ietf.org

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/queries/hard.json

## Acceptance Criteria
- Evidence pass rate increases from ~0% to >30%
- Correct answers with reputable sources pass

title: Improve answer synthesis fallbacks - mark as no-answer

comments.author: samaydhawan
comments.text:
## Problem
When providers dont return a direct answer, several fall back to snippet concatenation:
```python
if not answer:
    answer = " ".join(snippets[:2]).strip()
```

This produces poor "answers" that unfairly penalize providers in grading.

## Current behavior
parallel.py, brave.py, linkup.py all concatenate snippets as fallback.

## Proposed Fix
Option A: Mark as explicit no-answer
```python
if not answer:
    return SearchResult(
        answer="",
        error="no_synthesized_answer",
        ...
    )
```

Option B: Add answer_source field
```python
@dataclass
class SearchResult:
    answer_source: str = "api"  # or "synthesized" or "none"
```

Then judge can handle differently.

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/providers/base.py (if adding field)
- searchbench/providers/parallel.py
- searchbench/providers/brave.py
- searchbench/providers/linkup.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- Clear distinction between API answers and synthesized fallbacks
- Grading accounts for answer source

title: Track API costs on error responses

comments.author: samaydhawan
comments.text:
## Problem
All providers set cost_usd=0.0 on error paths, but API calls were still made.
This understates actual benchmark costs.

## Location
Every provider file: exa.py, parallel.py, brave.py, linkup.py, tavily.py

Example from exa.py:
```python
except httpx.TimeoutException as exc:
    return SearchResult(
        cost_usd=0.0,  # Should be self.cost_per_query
        ...
    )
```

## Fix
Change error handlers to still charge cost_per_query since the API call was made.

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/providers/exa.py
- searchbench/providers/parallel.py
- searchbench/providers/brave.py
- searchbench/providers/linkup.py
- searchbench/providers/tavily.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- Error responses still count toward total_cost_usd
- Cost tracking is accurate for budget planning

title: Fix calibration algorithm - computing p99 of p99s

comments.author: samaydhawan
comments.text:
## Problem
The timeout calibration algorithm computes p99 of p99 values instead of p99 of raw latencies.

## Location
searchbench/calibrate.py:19-38

The code collects latency_p99_ms from each run (already a p99), then computes p99 of those. With 10 runs, this is essentially the maximum, over-inflating timeout suggestions.

## Fix (Recommended)
Use p95 of p99s with smaller buffer:
p95_of_p99s = _percentile(samples, 95)
suggested = int((p95_of_p99s * 1.1) / 1000)  # 10% buffer

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/calibrate.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- Calibration produces reasonable timeouts (not inflated)
- With 10+ runs, suggested timeouts are within 20% of actual p99

title: Use Rich console for styled CLI output

comments.author: samaydhawan
comments.text:
## Problem
Spec mentions using Rich for styled CLI output:
```python
from rich.console import Console
console = Console()
```

But implementation uses plain typer.echo() everywhere.

## Benefit
- Colored output for success/error/warning
- Progress bars for benchmark runs
- Tables for summary output
- Better readability

## Implementation
1. Add rich to requirements.txt (already a dep of typer)
2. Create console = Console() in cli.py
3. Replace typer.echo() with console.print()
4. Add [green], [red], [yellow] markup
5. Use rich.table.Table for summary output

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/cli.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- CLI output is styled and readable
- Errors shown in red, success in green
- Summary tables are formatted

title: Add JSON parsing error handling to all providers

comments.author: samaydhawan
comments.text:
## Problem
Only exa.py handles ValueError for invalid JSON responses:
```python
except ValueError as exc:
    return SearchResult(error="invalid_json", ...)
```

Other providers (brave, parallel, linkup, tavily) would crash on malformed responses.

## Fix
Add ValueError handling to all provider search() methods:
```python
except ValueError as exc:
    return SearchResult(
        error="invalid_json",
        raw_response={"error": str(exc), "body": response.text[:500]},
        ...
    )
```

## Files to Modify
- searchbench/providers/parallel.py
- searchbench/providers/brave.py
- searchbench/providers/linkup.py
- searchbench/providers/tavily.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- Malformed JSON returns error result, not exception
- Raw response includes truncated body for debugging
